papers.title: Habitable Worlds Observatory (HWO): Living Worlds Community Working Group: The Search for Life on Potentially Habitable Exoplanets
papers.abstract: The discovery of a biosphere on another planet would transform how we view ourselves, and our planet Earth, in relation to the rest of the cosmos. We now know Earth is one planet among eight circling our sun; our sun is part of a swirling galaxy of over one hundred billion other suns; and our galaxy is one of untold billions in the universe. While we do not yet know how many, if any, other biospheres exist on the countless worlds orbiting countless other suns, we stand at the precipice of a new era of discovery, enabled by powerful new facilities able to peer across the light years into the atmospheres of planets similar to our own. This article is an adaptation of a science case document (SCDD) developed for the NASA Astrophysics Flagship mission the Habitable Worlds Observatory (HWO) Science, Technology, and Architecture Review Team (START) Living Worlds Community Working Group.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine finding out we're not alone in the universe—that somewhere among the billions of stars twinkling in our night sky, there's another world teeming with life. This discovery would fundamentally change how we see ourselves and our place in the cosmos, much like when we first realized Earth orbits the Sun rather than being the center of everything. Scientists are now closer than ever to answering one of humanity's most profound questions: Is there life beyond Earth? With over 100 billion stars in our galaxy alone, and billions of galaxies beyond that, the universe contains more potential homes for life than grains of sand on all Earth's beaches combined.

**What They Did**

This research isn't about a single discovery, but rather a comprehensive plan for humanity's most ambitious hunt for alien life. Scientists have designed a roadmap for the Habitable Worlds Observatory, a revolutionary space telescope that will act like a cosmic detective. Think of it as a super-powered magnifying glass that can peek into the atmospheres of Earth-like planets orbiting other stars—worlds that might be millions or billions of miles away. The team brought together experts from around the globe to determine exactly what this telescope should look for and how it should operate to maximize our chances of finding signs of life in these distant atmospheres.

**Key Findings**

Rather than reporting new discoveries, this work establishes the scientific foundation for future breakthroughs. The researchers have identified the key "biosignatures"—chemical fingerprints that would indicate life—that the telescope should search for in alien atmospheres. They've also mapped out which types of planets offer the best chances of harboring life and determined the technical capabilities needed to study them effectively.

**Looking Forward**

This roadmap sets the stage for what could be the most important scientific discovery in human history. The Habitable Worlds Observatory will launch within the next two decades, equipped to analyze dozens of potentially habitable worlds. If successful, we might finally answer whether Earth's story of life is unique or part of a much grander, more populated universe.

papers.title: Demographics of Close-In TESS Exoplanets Orbiting FGK Main-sequence Stars
papers.abstract: Understanding the demographics of close-in planets is crucial for insights into exoplanet formation and evolution. We present a detailed analysis of occurrence rates for close-in (0.5-16 day) planets with radii between 2 and 20$\,R_{\oplus}$ around FGK main-sequence stars. Our study uses a comprehensive sample from four years of TESS Science Processing Operations Center full-frame image data cross-matched with Gaia, analysed through our rigorous detection, vetting, and validation pipeline. Using high-confidence planet candidates, we apply a hierarchical Bayesian model to determine occurrence rates in the two-dimensional orbital period-radius plane. Our results are presented using 10-by-10 bins across the period-radius parameter space, offering unprecedented resolution and statistical precision. We find an overall occurrence rate of $9.4^{+0.7}_{-0.6}\%$. When using identical binning, our occurrence rate posteriors distributions align with Kepler's but have a magnitude smaller uncertainties on average. For hot Jupiters, we estimate the overall occurrence rate of $0.39^{+0.03}_{-0.02}\%$. This value is consistent with the previous Kepler FGK-type result within $1σ$. We find an overall occurrence rate of Neptunian desert planets of $0.08\pm0.01\%$, to our knowledge the first such determination. Additionally, in a volume-limited Gaia subsample within 100 pc in the same parameter region, we measure an overall planet occurrence rate of $15.4^{+1.6}_{-1.5}\%$ and a hot Jupiter occurrence rate of $0.42^{+0.16}_{-0.12}\%$. Our results establishes an improved foundation for constraining theoretical models of exoplanet populations.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

For centuries, we wondered if planets like Earth were rare cosmic accidents or common features of the universe. Thanks to powerful space telescopes, we now know that planets are everywhere—but we're still figuring out what kinds of planets are most common and where they tend to form. This research tackles a particularly intriguing puzzle: the strange worlds that orbit incredibly close to their stars, completing full "years" in just days or weeks. These scorching planets, which include everything from super-sized Earths to gas giants larger than Jupiter, hold crucial clues about how planetary systems form and evolve. Understanding their abundance helps us piece together the story of planet formation—including how rare or common Earth-like worlds might be.

**What They Did**

The researchers analyzed four years of data from TESS (Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite), a space telescope that watches for the tiny dimming that occurs when a planet passes in front of its star. Think of it like watching for the shadow of a moth crossing a distant streetlight. They focused on planets orbiting sun-like stars and took orbits lasting between half a day and 16 days—imagine worlds where a "year" is shorter than a typical vacation. The team then used sophisticated statistical methods to account for the planets they might have missed, similar to how pollsters adjust their samples to represent the broader population. This allowed them to calculate what percentage of sun-like stars actually host these close-orbiting worlds.

**Key Findings**

The results reveal that close-in planets are surprisingly common. Overall, about 9.4% of sun-like stars host at least one planet orbiting closer than Mercury does to our Sun. The famous "hot Jupiters"—gas giants that complete their orbits in days—appear around roughly 0.4% of stars, confirming previous estimates. Perhaps most intriguingly, they found that planets in the so-called "Neptunian desert"—a mysterious gap where Neptune-sized planets seem to avoid forming—occur around just 0.08% of stars, providing the first precise measurement of this cosmic rarity.

**Looking Forward**

These findings provide astronomers with a detailed census that will help refine theories about how planets form and migrate to their final orbits. The data suggests that the processes creating close-in planets are remarkably consistent across our galaxy. This work sets the stage for future missions that will study these worlds' atmospheres and compositions, potentially revealing how planetary systems evolve and what conditions might favor the formation of habitable worlds like Earth.

papers.title: Mass estimates of the young TOI-451 transiting planets: Multidimensional Gaussian Process on stellar spectroscopic and photometric signals
papers.abstract: The young TOI-451 planetary system, aged 125 Myr, provides a unique opportunity to test theories of planetary internal structures and atmospheric mass loss through examination of its three transiting planets. We present an exhaustive photometric and spectroscopic follow-up to determine the orbital and physical properties of the system. We perform multidimensional Gaussian Process regression with the code pyaneti on spectroscopic time-series and NGTS/LCO light curves to disentangle the stellar and planetary signal in ESPRESSO radial velocities. We show how contemporaneous photometry serves as an activity indicator to inform RV modelling within a multidimensional Gaussian Processes framework. We argue that this can be exploited when spectroscopic observations are adversely affected by low signal-to-noise and/or poor sampling. We estimate the Doppler semi-amplitudes of Kb = 2.6(+1.1,-1.2) m/s, Kc = 1.2(+1.0,-0.8) m/s and Kd = 2.7 +/- 1.2 m/s. This translates into 2-sigma mass estimates for TOI-451 b and d of Mb = 4.7(+2.1,-2.2) Earth masses and Md = 10.2(+4.6,-4.5) Earth masses, as well as a mass upper limit for TOI-451 c of Mc < 11.5 Earth masses. The derived planetary properties suggest that planets c and d contain significant hydrogen-rich envelopes. The inferred parameters of TOI-451 b are consistent with either a rocky world that still retains a small hydrogen envelope or a water world. These insights make the TOI-451 system an ideal laboratory for future follow-up studies aimed at measuring atmospheric compositions, detecting atmospheric mass-loss signatures, and further exploring planetary formation and evolution processes.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine catching a glimpse of our solar system when it was just a baby—that's essentially what astronomers have done with TOI-451, a planetary system only 125 million years old. While that sounds ancient, it's practically infantile compared to our 4.6-billion-year-old solar system. This cosmic nursery gives us a rare window into how planets evolve, lose their atmospheres, and transform over time. Understanding these young worlds helps answer fundamental questions: How do planets like Earth form? What makes some planets keep their atmospheres while others lose them to space? By studying TOI-451, we're essentially looking at planetary adolescence—a crucial period that shaped the worlds we see today.

**What They Did**

The research team used advanced telescopes to measure tiny wobbles in the star TOI-451 as its three planets tug on it gravitationally—like watching a person being gently pulled back and forth by invisible dance partners. This technique, called the radial velocity method, reveals how massive each planet is. The challenge was separating the planets' gravitational signals from the star's own natural brightness fluctuations, which can mask planetary signatures. To solve this, the researchers used sophisticated computer modeling that simultaneously analyzed the star's light patterns and its wobbling motion, essentially teaching their software to distinguish between stellar hiccups and genuine planetary pulls.

**Key Findings**

The team successfully weighed all three planets in this young system. The innermost planet, TOI-451 b, weighs about 4.7 times more than Earth and could be either a rocky world with a thin atmosphere or a "water world" rich in H2O. The middle planet, TOI-451 c, proved more elusive—they could only establish it weighs less than 11.5 Earth masses. The outermost planet, TOI-451 d, tips the scales at roughly 10 Earth masses and likely sports a thick, hydrogen-rich atmosphere that makes it puffy and Neptune-like.

**Looking Forward**

This research transforms TOI-451 into a cosmic laboratory for studying planetary evolution. Since these worlds are young, astronomers can potentially observe atmospheric loss in real-time and test theories about how planets shed their gaseous envelopes. Future observations with advanced telescopes could reveal the atmospheric compositions of these planets and catch them in the act of losing gas to space, providing unprecedented insights into the forces that sculpt planetary systems over cosmic time.

papers.title: High-fidelity lunar topographic reconstruction across diverse terrain and illumination environments using deep learning
papers.abstract: Topographic models are essential for characterizing planetary surfaces and for inferring underlying geological processes. Nevertheless, meter-scale topographic data remain limited, which constrains detailed planetary investigations, even for the Moon, where extensive high-resolution orbital images are available. Recent advances in deep learning (DL) exploit single-view imagery, constrained by low-resolution topography, for fast and flexible reconstruction of fine-scale topography. However, their robustness and general applicability across diverse lunar landforms and illumination conditions remain insufficiently explored. In this study, we build upon our previously proposed DL framework by incorporating a more robust scale recovery scheme and extending the model to polar regions under low solar illumination conditions. We demonstrate that, compared with single-view shape-from-shading methods, the proposed DL approach exhibits greater robustness to varying illumination and achieves more consistent and accurate topographic reconstructions. Furthermore, it reliably reconstructs topography across lunar features of diverse scales, morphologies, and geological ages. High-quality topographic models are also produced for the lunar south polar areas, including permanently shadowed regions, demonstrating the method's capability in reconstructing complex and low-illumination terrain. These findings suggest that DL-based approaches have the potential to leverage extensive lunar datasets to support advanced exploration missions and enable investigations of the Moon at unprecedented topographic resolution.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**
Creating detailed 3D maps of planetary surfaces is crucial for understanding how worlds like the Moon formed and evolved over billions of years. Despite having thousands of high-resolution photos of the Moon, scientists still lack the meter-scale topographic data needed for detailed geological investigations and planning future landing missions.

**What They Did**
The researchers developed an advanced artificial intelligence system that can create highly detailed 3D terrain maps using just single photographs of the lunar surface. They trained their deep learning model to work across different types of lunar landscapes and lighting conditions, including the challenging permanently shadowed regions near the Moon's south pole where future missions may land.

**Key Findings**
The AI system proved remarkably robust, successfully reconstructing fine-scale topography across diverse lunar features regardless of their size, shape, or geological age. Unlike traditional methods that struggle with varying sunlight conditions, this approach maintained consistent accuracy even in areas with poor illumination. The system generated high-quality 3D models of the lunar south polar regions, including areas that never see direct sunlight. Most impressively, it outperformed existing single-image reconstruction techniques while being much faster and more flexible than conventional methods.

**Looking Forward**
This breakthrough could revolutionize how we map not just the Moon, but other planetary bodies throughout the solar system. With vast archives of orbital imagery already available, scientists could rapidly generate unprecedented high-resolution topographic maps to support upcoming lunar missions and advance our understanding of planetary geology at scales never before possible.

papers.title: True Masses using RV data with Hipparcos and Gaia Astrometry
papers.abstract: Long-period companions are detected and characterized thanks to long-baseline radial velocity surveys. Combining Doppler time-series with astrometry, and in particular with proper motion anomalies technique, it is possible to put strong constraints on their orbital inclination and true mass. This work aims to present a model that combines Hipparcos and Gaia astrometric data with radial velocity measurements to constrain the orbital inclinations and true masses of long-period companions. Additionally, we re-analyse a small sample of targets that have not yet been studied using this combined approach. This research leverages the simultaneous modelling of proper motion anomalies and radial velocities, in conjunction with an analysis of the sensitivity curve. This approach serves not only as a verification of the parameters but also as a means to acquire valuable insights into planetary systems. The new analyses reveal that some of the targets classified as brown dwarfs or small-mass stars have a planetary nature. HD 5388 b and HD 6718 b are likely planets. HD 141937 b is likely a planet, but the current dataset does not allow us to firmly constrain its true mass. HD 16760 b belongs to the brown dwarf regime and it has a probable second companion. 30 Ari B b falls within the stellar regime, but the presence of an additional stellar companion could compromise the reliability of the final results. For HD 148427 b, HD 96127 b and HIP 65891 b we determined a range for the orbital inclinations.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to weigh an invisible bowling ball by watching how it makes a rope swing when tied to the other end. That's essentially the challenge astronomers face when studying distant planets orbiting other stars. For decades, we've been finding these "exoplanets" by detecting their gravitational tugs on their host stars, but determining their actual masses—a crucial detail for understanding what they're made of and whether they could support life—has remained frustratingly difficult. This research tackles that fundamental problem, helping us distinguish between true planets, failed stars called brown dwarfs, and small stellar companions. Getting these classifications right is essential for understanding how planetary systems form and for identifying worlds that might be habitable.

**What They Did**

The researchers combined two powerful detective techniques to solve the mass mystery. First, they used radial velocity measurements—essentially watching stars wobble back and forth as unseen companions orbit them, like watching a parent spin around while holding a child's hands. Second, they analyzed tiny changes in how stars move across the sky over decades, comparing ultra-precise measurements from two space missions: Hipparcos (launched in 1989) and Gaia (launched in 2013). By combining these complementary approaches, they could determine not just that something was orbiting these stars, but also the angle at which we're viewing the orbit—the key missing piece needed to calculate true masses rather than just minimum estimates.

**Key Findings**

The team re-examined eight mysterious objects and discovered that some previously misclassified companions are actually planets in disguise. Two objects around stars HD 5388 and HD 6718 turned out to be planets rather than brown dwarfs. Another companion around HD 141937 likely falls into the planetary category, though more data is needed for certainty. However, HD 16760's companion confirmed its status as a brown dwarf—a "failed star" too small to sustain nuclear fusion—and revealed hints of a second hidden companion in the system.

**Looking Forward**

This work demonstrates how combining different observational techniques can revolutionize our understanding of distant worlds. As Gaia continues collecting data and future space missions provide even more precise measurements, we'll be able to determine true masses for thousands of exoplanets. This will help astronomers better understand how planetary systems form and evolve, and more accurately identify Earth-like worlds that might harbor life.

papers.title: Constraining the size, shape, and albedo of the large Trans-Neptunian Object (28978) Ixion with multi-chord stellar occultations
papers.abstract: Trans-Neptunian objects (TNOs) are among the most primitive remnants of the early Solar System, and constraining their sizes, shapes, albedos, and surface properties is essential for understanding their origin and evolution. Stellar occultations provide highly accurate size and shape measurements for TNOs, while photometry constrains their albedo and surface colours. (28978) Ixion is one of the largest TNOs and a prominent Plutino, making it a key target for comparative studies. We aim to constrain Ixion's projected size, shape, absolute magnitude, geometric albedo, and surface colours, and to search for evidence of an atmosphere or circum-object material. We analysed stellar occultation campaigns by Ixion conducted between 2020 and 2023 within the Lucky Star collaboration, comprising 51 observations from eight events, including 30 positive detections. Five multi-chord events enabled a global limb fit and an accurate reconstruction of Ixion's projected shape. The occultations reveal a slightly elongated limb well represented by a single projected ellipse, yielding an area-equivalent diameter of $D_{\mathrm{equiv}} = 696.78^{+10.75}_{-8.87}$ km and an apparent oblateness $ε' = 0.081^{+0.004}_{-0.010}$. Typical radial residuals of order $\sim$10 km indicate a largely stable shape across epochs, with modest epoch-dependent variations. Calibrated photometric data yield an absolute magnitude of $H_V = 3.845 \pm 0.006$, a phase-curve slope of $β= 0.1301 \pm 0.0078$ mag deg$^{-1}$, and a visible geometric albedo of $p_V = 0.106^{+0.003}_{-0.003}$, with colours consistent with moderately red TNO surfaces. No atmosphere or circum-object material is detected down to our sensitivity limits. The best-sampled event also allows a precise measurement of the angular diameter of the occulted star Gaia DR3 4056440205544338944, $θ_\star = 0.670 \pm 0.010$ mas.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Our solar system extends far beyond the familiar planets, into a mysterious realm of icy worlds called Trans-Neptunian Objects—ancient remnants from when our solar system was first forming 4.6 billion years ago. These distant objects are like cosmic time capsules, preserving clues about the raw materials and processes that built the planets we know today. Understanding these primitive worlds helps us piece together the story of how Earth and the other planets came to be, and reveals the incredible diversity of objects that populate planetary systems throughout the universe.

**What They Did**

Scientists used a clever technique called stellar occultation to study Ixion, one of the largest of these distant icy worlds. Think of it like watching Ixion's shadow as it passes in front of a distant star—just as you might block out the sun with your thumb to study its size and shape. When Ixion moved between Earth and a background star, it created a brief shadow that swept across our planet. By coordinating 51 telescopes around the world during eight different shadow events between 2020 and 2023, researchers could precisely measure how long the star disappeared from each location. This gave them multiple "chords" cutting across Ixion's silhouette, like slicing through an apple to understand its shape.

**Key Findings**

Ixion turned out to be roughly 697 kilometers across—about the width of Texas—making it significantly smaller than our Moon but still one of the largest objects in the outer solar system. The measurements revealed it's slightly oval-shaped rather than perfectly round, stretched out by about 8%. Its surface is quite dark, reflecting only about 11% of the sunlight that hits it—darker than charcoal but brighter than fresh asphalt. The researchers found no evidence of an atmosphere or rings around Ixion.

**Looking Forward**

These precise measurements of Ixion provide a crucial benchmark for understanding how large icy worlds form and evolve in the outer reaches of planetary systems. As we discover similar objects around other stars, Ixion serves as a local example of what these distant worlds might be like, helping us understand the full diversity of planetary system architecture across the galaxy.

Why It Matters

Our solar system extends far beyond the familiar planets, into a mysterious realm of icy worlds called Trans-Neptunian Objects—ancient remnants from when our solar system was first forming 4.6 billion years ago. These distant objects are like cosmic time capsules, preserving clues about the raw materials and processes that built the planets we know today. Understanding these primitive worlds helps us piece together the story of how Earth and the other planets came to be, and reveals the incredible diversity of objects that populate planetary systems throughout the universe.

What They Did

Scientists used a clever technique called stellar occultation to study Ixion, one of the largest of these distant icy worlds. Think of it like watching Ixion's shadow as it passes in front of a distant star—just as you might block out the sun with your thumb to study its size and shape. When Ixion moved between Earth and a background star, it created a brief shadow that swept across our planet. By coordinating 51 telescopes around the world during eight different shadow events between 2020 and 2023, researchers could precisely measure how long the star disappeared from each location. This gave them multiple "chords" cutting across Ixion's silhouette, like slicing through an apple to understand its shape.

Key Findings

Ixion turned out to be roughly 697 kilometers across—about the width of Texas—making it significantly smaller than our Moon but still one of the largest objects in the outer solar system. The measurements revealed it's slightly oval-shaped rather than perfectly round, stretched out by about 8%. Its surface is quite dark, reflecting only about 11% of the sunlight that hits it—darker than charcoal but brighter than fresh asphalt. The researchers found no evidence of an atmosphere or rings around Ixion.

Looking Forward

These precise measurements of Ixion provide a crucial benchmark for understanding how large icy worlds form and evolve in the outer reaches of planetary systems. As we discover similar objects around other stars, Ixion serves as a local example of what these distant worlds might be like, helping us understand the full diversity of planetary system architecture across the galaxy.

tweet_hook.evidence: Multi-chord occultations from 51 observations show oblateness of 0.081 and 10.6% albedo

papers.title: Parallaxes, Proper Motions, and Near-Infrared Photometry for 173 L and T Dwarfs From The US Naval Observatory Infrared Astrometry Program
papers.abstract: We present near-infrared parallax and proper motion astrometry for 74 L-dwarfs and 99 T-dwarfs, as single objects or in binary systems, obtained with the ASTROCAM astrometric imager on the USNO, Flagstaff Station 1.55-m telescope over two observing periods. For all 173 objects the median number of observational epochs was 62 with a median time frame of 5.25 years, resulting in median uncertainties of $σ$($π_{abs}$) = 1.51 mas, $σ$($μ_{abs}$) = 1.02 mas yr$^{-1}$, and $σ$($V_{\rm tan}$) = 1.01 km s$^{-1}$. Our observations provide the first parallax/proper motion results for 16 objects and the highest precision parallaxes/proper motions for an additional 116 objects. A serendipitous overlap of 40 objects with Gaia DR3 astrometry allows direct comparison and confirmation of our results, along with an investigation on the effects of resolved binarity on astrometric results. We also provide a uniform set of $J$-, $H$-, $K_{S}$-band photometry in the UKIRT/MKO system, most of it being from new observations. We use these results to examine objects included in this study of special-interest populations, consisting of binaries, wide companions, young objects, subdwarfs, and brown dwarf spectral standards.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to find planets around stars so dim they're barely visible, even with powerful telescopes. Brown dwarfs—often called "failed stars"—are cosmic objects that never got quite massive enough to ignite nuclear fusion like our Sun. These mysterious objects blur the line between planets and stars, and studying them helps us understand how planetary systems form and evolve. By precisely tracking the movements and distances of these elusive brown dwarfs, astronomers can better understand the building blocks of our galaxy and potentially discover new worlds orbiting these dim stellar cousins.

**What They Did**

Using a specialized telescope in Arizona over more than five years, researchers carefully tracked 173 brown dwarfs as they moved across the sky. Think of it like watching fireflies on a summer night—except these "fireflies" are light-years away and barely glowing in infrared light. The team measured two key things: how far away these objects are (called parallax, similar to how your finger appears to shift when you close one eye, then the other) and how fast they're moving sideways across space (proper motion). They took an average of 62 observations per object, creating an incredibly detailed map of these brown dwarfs' locations and movements through space.

**Key Findings**

The study achieved remarkable precision, measuring distances accurate to within about 1.5 milliarcseconds—imagine spotting a quarter from 100 miles away. For 16 brown dwarfs, this represents the first time anyone has precisely measured their distance and movement. The team also created the most accurate measurements yet for 116 additional objects. Their results matched beautifully with data from the European Space Agency's Gaia spacecraft, confirming the reliability of both datasets.

**Looking Forward**

These precise measurements create a crucial foundation for future discoveries. By knowing exactly where brown dwarfs are and how they move, astronomers can better search for planets orbiting them and understand how these systems compare to our own solar system. This work also helps refine our understanding of how stars and planets form throughout the galaxy.

papers.title: Semi-convection in rotating spherical shells: flows, layers and dynamos
papers.abstract: Large regions of gaseous planets are thought to be stratified with an unstable thermal gradient, but a stabilising gradient of heavy element composition. Fluid in these regions is unstable to semi-convection, with motions driven by differences in the molecular diffusivity of temperature and composition, and could play a role in supporting planetary magnetic fields. Previous studies focus largely on local models in Cartesian boxes; here, we investigate semi-convection in rotating spherical shells. The onset of linear instability shows a transition between the two limits of rotating convection and non-rotating semi-convection. Non-linear simulations evolve into a system of concentric layers of relatively constant density, separated by narrow high-gradient regions. These layers gradually merge, resulting in a statistically steady state dominated by either a single convection region or a narrower convective zone beneath a stably stratified layer (SSL), depending on the strength of the thermal forcing compared to the rotation. When magnetic field generation is considered, our magnetohydrodynamic simulations exhibit self-sustained dynamo action. In cases where the turbulent convective region generates magnetic fields that are smoothed by zonal flows within the overlying SSL, the resulting field is strongly dipolar and axisymmetric, in encouraging agreement with Saturn's observed magnetic field. Within the regimes explored, both the Rossby number and the thickness of the SSL are well predicted by a single combination of control parameters. This enables the identification of a parameter range in which the generated magnetic fields resemble those of planetary dynamos.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**
Giant planets like Saturn have magnetic fields that scientists don't fully understand, particularly how they're generated in regions where hot gas wants to rise but heavy elements create a "lid" that resists mixing. This research helps explain how these competing forces create the organized flows needed to power planetary magnetic fields, bringing us closer to understanding one of the solar system's most puzzling phenomena.

**What They Did**
The researchers used computer simulations to model what happens inside spherical shells of gas that rotate like planets, where temperature differences want to drive convection but heavier elements resist it—a process called semi-convection. Unlike previous studies that looked at simplified rectangular boxes, they modeled the full spherical geometry and rotation of real planets, then added magnetic fields to see how they behave.

**Key Findings**
The simulations revealed that semi-convection creates distinct layers of gas separated by sharp boundaries, like a stack of pancakes with different densities. These layers gradually merge over time into either a single churning convection zone or a narrow convective region topped by a stable layer, depending on how much heat is driving the system compared to the rotation rate. When magnetic fields were included, the models generated self-sustaining planetary dynamos. Most remarkably, cases where magnetic fields were smoothed by the stable upper layer produced strongly dipolar, symmetric magnetic fields that closely match Saturn's actual magnetic field.

**Looking Forward**
This work provides a new framework for predicting when planets will generate Earth-like magnetic fields versus more complex field structures. The research could help scientists better understand magnetic field generation across the solar system and guide future space missions in interpreting magnetic field measurements from giant planets and their moons.
